“Who’d raise a hand against a servant of the Gods? Of course, evil knows no bounds, but I have faith in Faelan,” he points at the man standing next to him. “He is more than capable of shielding me from harm.”
The man smiles unpleasantly, still fixing you with his eyes. Suddenly you realize that you can’t move. Your legs and arm stiffen and become heavy as if filled with lead. The man smirks disdainfully and looks away, releasing you.
“Gods have blessed Faelan with great powers, far above those of mere mortals. He was lost for a long time, but he serves a great cause now, as do we all.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What do the gods want? What is the divine will?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Of that I have no doubt, my child. On the surface, your deeds seem to speak for themselves – they tell me that your heart is in the right place. And yet, there are some who say that it’s nothing but an act, that you are not a <man/woman> to be trusted, which is a most grievous charge.”
“Master Feng - my new loremaster. He is a very pious and humble man, not the type to speak against someone without a reason.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Feng and I go a way back. He wanted me to kill his rival, but I refused and Feng had to flee.”
[streetwise success]“Yet speak he did. Did he say how he came to possess such knowledge?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Master Feng came here because he’s heard the divine call,” Meru says sternly. “He prayed for three days and nights in front of the city walls, refusing to enter the city before he cleanses himself through prayer and fasting.
“I pride myself on being a good judge of character and I can assure you that master Feng isn’t someone who plots murder. You, on the other hand, I’m not so sure about.
“Remove yourself from my presence.”
“He didn’t elaborate and seemed hesitant to speak about it at first, but he felt that he had to warn me. He said you had the reputation of an untrustworthy character with few redeeming qualities.”

dlgAnsw.text: [persuasion][charisma]“So you will condemn me based on hearsay then? Despite the fact that my deeds, as you say, speak for themselves? Test my faith and devotion and see for yourself!”
[streetwise][charisma]“It is sad that people outside these walls look at the faithful with suspicion and mistrust, but it is sadder still when this mistrust is used against them in this holy city.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “You who claim to be the chosen one?”

dlgAnsw.text: “The hearts of the righteous shall not know doubt.”

“I *claim* to be chosen, not all knowing. The gods have told to me to come here, for it is in this holy city that my destiny will be revealed. I didn’t feel that it was my place to question them, but I would question my brother in the faith to better understand the path the gods have laid down for me.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Only a fool believes everything he is told. Yet your heart appears to be in the right place and I can’t blame you for being overzealous and wanting to play a bigger role, can I?” asks Meru, emphasizing the last two words.

dlgAnsw.text: “Was my arrival not foretold? Were there not signs that the Gods have finally chosen a shepherd of their flock?”
“When you doubt me, you doubt the very Gods you claim to serve, for they are the ones who guide my hand and soul.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Of course,” says Meru, indicating that the discussion is over, at least for now. “Ask your questions.”
“The Gods sent you to me, not the other way around,” snaps Meru. “You'd to well to remember it. Now, ask your questions.”

“Your arrival was foretold because you told everyone who'd listen that you were on your way here. Your faith can’t be questioned, this much is true, but your pride will be your downfall, <brother/sister>.
“Ask your questions.”

“The Gods spoke to me. Like everyone else I was blind, until the fog was lifted from my eyes and I could see the truth that was there all along.
“It wasn’t the war that caused the downfall, it was our pride. We didn't want to accept the gods before the war, and we didn't want to accept them after they had helped us defeat our enemies. That's why they left. That's why we were punished.”

dlgAnsw.text: “And you think you can bring them back?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I’m but a man,” says Meru. “I can only open the gateways and pray that they come forth and deliver us from wickedness we inflicted on ourselves.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What makes you think they have our best interests at heart?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “What heresy is this?” Meru asks angrily, glancing at his guards. “If I didn’t know better...”

dlgAnsw.text: [etiquette success]“Forgive me for questioning you in such a direct manner, Brother. I merely wish to hear you speak on this most worthy subject.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “A vast distance lies between the mortal plane and the realm of the Gods. This void can’t be navigated for it is greater even than the largest ocean, but it can be crossed with the aid of great engines that can manipulate the very fabric of reality, folding it like a cloth and bringing infinitely distant entry points together for a brief moment.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What makes you think they have our best interests at heart?”
“Yet you said that the Gods spoke to you?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Promotor fidei?” sighs Meru. “I suppose it is fitting for me to be a Promoter of the Cause. Very well, I’ll play along if only to help you cast away the doubts.
“We know the Gods descended from heaven in our hour of need when all seemed lost. They saved us, prevented the flame of mankind to be extinguished for good. We owe the Gods *everything* for without them we would have had nothing. So how can we doubt them? How can we doubt their intent? How can we doubt their love?”

dlgAnsw.text: “So we should just give them the reins and hope for the best?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“You have to ask yourself,” says Meru, falling into a familiar rhythm, his voice becoming deeply resonant, “who amongst us is fit to rule? Is it Gaelius? A strong man by all accounts, but a man nonetheless. He fears what he doesn’t understand and his fear becomes the law. Would you pledge allegiance to such a man and follow him blindly or would you rather follow those who are worthy of worship?
“Maybe it’s Antidas? A man who couldn’t keep what he got from his father and made one blunder after another. We all make mistakes. To err is human, after all, but would you pledge allegiance to a man who doesn’t know what he’s doing?”

“You have to ask yourself,” says Meru, falling into a familiar rhythm, his voice becoming deeply resonant, “who amongst us is fit to rule? Is it Serenas? An unworthy man who’s sitting on the throne of a once noble House because he’s distantly related to Gaelius? Would you pledge allegiance to such a man and follow him blindly or would you rather follow those who are worthy of worship?
“Maybe it’s Antidas? A man who couldn’t keep what he got from his father and made one blunder after another. We all make mistakes. To err is human, after all, but would you pledge allegiance to a man who doesn’t know what he’s doing?”

“Only the Gods are infallible. Only they have the wisdom to guide us.
“Wisdom comes with age. An ancient patriarch is wiser than a young man, yet even the oldest patriarch is nothing but a mewling babe compared to those who have neither beginning nor end, those who are as old as the world itself. What sane man would bend a knee to a child when he can bow to and follow a sage?
“Thus if bow we shall, if kneel we must, would you not kneel in front of an all-knowing and infallible God rather than in front of a mere man whose very flawed nature makes him unfit to rule? Where is our godless civilization of old? Mighty it was yet it was gone in an instant. What chance do *we* have?
“We tried the godless way and it cost us dearly. I say the time has come to try a different way. After all, we don’t have much to lose, do we?”

dlgAnsw.text: “You said that the Gods spoke to you?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “There are ways,” says Meru confidently, like a man who knows too well what he’s talking about. “Continue on the path the Gods set out for you and I’ll take you to a holy place where your faith will be tested.”
“Are you surprised? You who claim to be guided by the Gods?”

dlgAnsw.text: “Not at all, brother. I was merely curious as to how it happened so that I can compare it with my own experience.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “The divine manifestations can be very... overwhelming. Only those whose faith is their shield can survive the experience.”
“Man has strayed from the path. When we open our hearts and our souls to the Gods, then they will return and watch over us like a shepherd watches his flock.”
“If only it was that easy,” says Meru, shaking his head slowly. “Only when the Houses of men fall and the House of Worship rises again, will they return to guide us.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Is this why you no longer call yourself a lord?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “It was shown to me, over and over again. A pyramid rising from the sands, a blinding beacon of light penetrating the darkness, symbolizing ignorance and petty struggles. The holy Al-Akia.”

“The true Lords are up there,” says Meru pointing up, “in their heavenly abode, waiting for us to cast down the false lords and bow to the divine. Once the truth was revealed to me, I could no longer claim the title that wasn't mine to bear.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Even if you don't call yourself a lord, you still rule this city.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Must not a shepherd watch over his flock? Must I abandon these people in their hour of need?”

“I will oversee all matters of faith, Paullus will oversee the rest. If he doesn’t think I’m offering enough, he’s a damn fool.”

“I’m grateful for his support,” Meru says humbly, bowing his head, “although when I requested a legatus, I hoped <he/she> would be accompanied by a legion not a handful of soldiers. Paullus does like playing it safe but sooner or later he would have to make a decision. Let us both pray that it won’t be too late.
“As for you, Legatus, my men will be ready within a day. I’m sure you’ll need some time to prepare as well.”

“The Gods have revealed the location of Al-Akia to me. It’s been lost for centuries, shrouded in darkness of our ignorance. The time has come to restore this holy site to its former glory, returning it to the faithful. Imagine, standing where the gods stood when they descended from their heavenly abode and took on mortal forms to walk with us, kissing the ground made holy by their presence.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What do you want me to do?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I want you to secure the site while my men explore it. I know you will do your best. Unlike Paullus, I have full confidence in you.”

“I can only imagine your disappointment, Praetor. I’ve heard you took a liking to young Serenas and even advised him on matters of city governance. Too bad he didn’t seek your advice when he decided to attack the Slums. I’m sure you would have warned him of the consequences.”

“Your visit is a rare opportunity, Praetor. I want you to return to Teron a believer and I'll do whatever it takes to open your heart and your eyes. I want you see the holy Al-Akia with your own eyes because I want you to believe.”
